{{other}} {{no footnotes|date=January 2014}} {{Use dmy dates|date=January 2018}} {{Use British English|date=January 2018}} [[File:Thornton sheild.jpg|right|thumb|upright|Domestic armorial window]] '''William Warrington''', (1796–1869), was an English maker of [[stained glass]] windows. His firm, operating from 1832 to 1875, was one of the earliest of the English [[Gothic revival|Medieval revival]] and served clients such as Norwich and Peterborough Cathedrals. Warrington was an historian of medieval glass and published an illustrated book ''The History of Stained Glass''.
== Biographical ==
{{multiple image | align = right | direction = horizontal | header_align = center | header = Designs by Warrington
| image1 = Warrington frontispiece.jpg | width1 = 195 | alt1 = | caption1 = <center> Frontispiece with the cipher Warrington used in his windows
| image2 = Warrington design for House of Lords.jpg | width2 = 148 | alt2 = | caption2 = <center> An armorial window for the House of Lords.
| image3 = Warrington design for Norwich Cathedral.jpg | width3 = 154 | alt3 = | caption3 = <center>Design for [[Norwich Cathedral]] }} In his youth, Warrington first trained with his father as a painter of [[Heraldry|armorial]] shields. He then moved for a time into the stained glass workshop of [[Thomas Willement]], one of the earliest such workshops to be of high renown. In 1832 Warrington established his own stained glass company, where he produced windows that well satisfied the rising fashion of [[Gothic Revival]] and in which his own skills as an armorial painter were utilised in the production of domestic as well as ecclesiastical windows.
From studying existent ancient windows and emulation of the leading techniques of the master Thomas Willement, Warrington developed a style which allowed him to create windows strongly resembling those of the [[Gothic art|13th and 14th centuries]] in appearance. His windows became the preferred choice of the architect [[Augustus Welby Northmore Pugin|Augustus Welby Pugin]] who used them in most of his earliest churches, between 1838 and 1842.
But Pugin was soon to fall out with Warrington, claiming ''“The Glass-Painters will shorten my days, they are the greatest plague I have. The reason I did not give Warrington the window at the hospital is this. He has lately become so conceited and got nearly as expensive as Willement.”''<ref>extract from a letter by Pugin in the Victoria and Albert Museum, London</ref>{{full|date=January 2014}} Warrington produced drawings of windows to be used by Pugin in the Houses of Parliament, but the firms that Pugin employed were [[Ballantine and Allen]] and [[Hardman & Co.]]
In 1848 Warrington published ''“The History of Stained Glass, from the Earliest Period of the Art to the Present Time”'' . The book came out in a folio edition with coloured lithographs illustrating British stained glass windows from the 11th to the 15th centuries. However Warrington expressed his dislike of the glass of the centuries that followed as being "a misconception and misapplication of this art."
Among Warrington's significant commissions was the tiered arrangement of windows for the Eastern Apse of [[Norwich Cathedral]]. He also designed for [[Ely Cathedral]], where his work may still be seen, both installed and on display in the Stained Glass Museum.
After Warrington’s death in 1869, the firm continued until 1875.
== Style ==
Warrington was able to reproduce closely the geometric and foliate backgrounds of the 13th century and create pictorial rondels composed of small pieces of glass that gave a similar impression to the Medieval originals, though tending to let through more light and have less luminosity, because the nature of the glass was less flawed and therefore less refractive. Warrington's windows often contain a background comprising a distinctive pattern of little red and blue diagonal checks which was copied from medieval originals. Many of Warrington’s [[Gothic Revival]] windows have a pleasant simplicity about them, the stylised foliage which takes up much of the window space being less heavy in appearance than some of his rivals, such as Clutterbuck, and based more closely upon recognisable plants.
The balance and arrangements of pictorial scenes within their formal background shows Warrington as a much more skilful designer than his teacher Willement, in whose windows the overall arrangement has a fairly arbitrary quality. Warrington’s figurative painting strives towards the [[Gothic art|Medieval]] in its forms, which are somewhat elongated and elegant, with simply-painted drapery falling in deep folds in such a way that line and movement is emphasised in the pictorial composition. His painting of the details, particularly of faces, is both masterly and exquisite. Towards the end of his career he also designed windows in a more painterly and less Gothic manner to suit changing tastes.
==Buildings containing windows by Warrington== [[File:Thornton Knight and Lady.jpg|thumb|upright|Domestic glass for a Medieval setting]]
* Ely Cathedral and also in the Stained Glass Museum at Ely Cathedral. * St Mary's College Oscott, near Birmingham - windows of saints designed by Pugin, made by Warrington, 1838. * St. Mary's R.C. Church, Sutton Coldfield, West Midlands - windows designed by Pugin, made by Warrington, 1838. * St Mary, Salehurst - a large 5 light West Window showing Christ before Pilate, Christ carrying the Cross, the Crucifixion, Noli me tangere and Ascension. * St. Margaret’s Church, Addington, Kent - the East window, 3 lights of the Ascension * St George's, Brede, Sussex - has three windows * All Saints’, Lindfield, Sussex - has three windows. * St Andrew’s, Hove - 2 windows, the Raising of Lazarus and the Raising of Jairus’ Daughter. * St John’s, Deptford - one window, Presentation in the Temple. * Norwich Cathedral - The windows of the Apsidal Eastern End. * Thornton College, Buckinghamshire - figurative, decorative and armorial windows. * [[Basilica of St. John the Baptist|Basilica Cathedral of St. John the Baptist]], [[St. John's, Newfoundland and Labrador, Canada]] - 7 windows * Presentation Convent, Cathedral Square, St. John's, Newfoundland and Labrador, Canada - 2 windows in Oratory Chapel, 1 window (three lights) in central hall * [[St Peter's Church, Heversham|St Peter's, Heversham]], Cumbria - 5 light East window of Jesus and the Gospel writers. * Lissadell Parish Church, Church of Ireland - a number of windows by Warrington * St Mary Magdalene, Albrighton, Wolverhampton. Signed window in south chancel * [[St. Anne's Chapel (Fredericton)]] has a triplet window by Warrington in the chancel St. John's Horninglow, Burton on Trent - five-light east window illustrative of the life of St. John the Evangelist. Given by Mr. H. E. Smith, Shelbrook House, Ashby de la Zouch<ref>Burton Chronicle 25 October 1866 page 4</ref> * [[Mount St Bernard Abbey]], Coalville, Leicestershire - quatrefoil window in original nave * [[All Saints Church, Leamington Spa]] (Leamington Priors) - two South Aisle windows (St James the Great, St John the Evangelist). St Peter missing since 1903. South Apse and South Chancel Clerestory 13 scenes of the life of Jesus re-set 1900 from original West window; one scene, Christ before Pilate, is missing.
== Other Early 19th century studios == * [[Thomas Willement]] * [[William Wailes]] * [[Charles Edmund Clutterbuck]] * [[Hardman & Co.]]
== See also == * [[Stained glass]] * [[Stained glass - British glass, 1811-1918]] * [[Victorian Era]] * [[Gothic Revival]]

{{wiktionary|wrongdoing}} {{redirect2|Wrongdoers|Wrong|the Norma Jean album|Wrongdoers (album)|other uses|Wrong (disambiguation)}} A '''wrong''' (from [[Old English]] ''wrang ''– ''crooked'')<ref name=oed>{{cite book|title=Oxford English Dictionary Second Edition on CD-ROM|year=2009|publisher=Oxford University Press|location=Oxford|chapter=crime}}</ref> is an act that is illegal or [[immoral]].<ref name="oxdic">{{cite book|title=Oxford Dictionary of Law|year=2003|publisher=Oxford University Press|location=Oxford|isbn=0198607563|author=Elizabeth A. Martin|edition=7}}</ref> '''Legal wrongs''' are usually quite clearly defined in the [[law]] of a [[State (polity)|state]] and/or [[jurisdiction]]. They can be divided into [[civil wrong]]s and [[crime]]s (or ''criminal offences'') in [[Common law (legal system)|common law]] countries,<ref name="oxdic" /> while [[Civil law (legal system)|civil law]] countries tend to have some additional categories, such as [[contraventions]].
'''[[Morality|Moral]] wrong''' is an underlying concept for legal wrong. Some moral wrongs are punishable by law, for example, [[rape]] or [[murder]].<ref name="oxdic" /> Other moral wrongs have nothing to do with law. On the other hand, some legal wrongs, such as parking offences, could hardly be classified as moral wrongs.<ref name="oxdic" />
==Legal wrong== In law, a wrong can be a legal [[injury]], which is any damage resulting from a violation of a [[legal right]]. A legal wrong can also imply the state of being contrary to the principles of justice or law. It means that something is contrary to conscience or morality and results in treating others unjustly. If the loss caused by a wrong is minor enough, there is no compensation, which principle is known as ''[[De minimis|de minimis non curat lex]]''. Otherwise, damages apply.
The law of England recognised the concept of a "wrong" before it recognised the distinction between [[civil wrong]]s (governed by [[Civil law (common law)|civil law]]) and [[crime]]s (defined by [[criminal law]]), which distinction was developed during the thirteenth century.<ref>[[Owen Hood Phillips|O. Hood Phillips]], [[A First Book of English Law]], Sweet and Maxwell, 4th ed., 1960, pp. 207, 208, 213</ref>
==See also== {{wikiquote|Wrongs}} *[[Error]] *[[Evil]] *[[Goodness and value theory]] *[[Guilt (law)]] *[[Justice]] *[[Moral rights]] *[[Natural and legal rights]] *[[Rights]]
==References== *Willis, Hugh. ''Principles of the Law of Damages''. The Keefe-Davidson Co.: St. Paul, 1910. {{reflist}}

{{Use dmy dates|date=February 2012}} {{Infobox Korean name|context=north| img=Yongbyon 5MWe Magnox reactor.jpg|caption=The 5 MWe experimental reactor| hangul=녕변핵시설| hanja=寧邊核設施| rr=Nyeongbyeon haeksiseol| mr=Nyŏngbyŏn haeksisŏl| }}
The '''Yongbyon Nuclear Scientific Research Center'''<ref>"Yongbyon" is spelled and pronounced 녕변 (Nyŏngbyŏn) in North Korea and 영변 (Yŏngbyŏn) in South Korea.</ref> is [[North Korea]]'s major nuclear facility, operating its first [[nuclear reactor]]s. It is located in [[Nyongbyon County]] in [[North Pyongan Province]], about 100 km north of [[Pyongyang]]. The center produced the [[fissile material]] for North Korea's [[List of nuclear weapons tests of North Korea|six nuclear weapon tests from 2006 to 2017]], and since 2009 is developing indigenous [[light water reactor]] nuclear power station technology. Since early 2018, nuclear testing at Yongbyon has ceased and the site has seen hardly any movement in activity.<ref name=oct31 />
==Facilities== The major installations include all aspects of a [[Magnox]] [[nuclear fuel cycle|nuclear reactor fuel cycle]], based on the use of [[natural uranium]] fuel: * a [[Nuclear fuel|fuel]] fabrication plant, * a 5 [[MWe]] experimental reactor producing power and district heating, * a short-term [[Spent nuclear fuel|spent fuel]] storage facility, * a [[Nuclear reprocessing|fuel reprocessing]] facility that recovers [[uranium]] and [[plutonium]] from [[spent nuclear fuel|spent fuel]] using the [[PUREX]] process.
Magnox spent fuel is not designed for long-term storage as both the casing and [[uranium]] metal core react with water; it is designed to be reprocessed within a few years of removal from a reactor.<ref name=RWMAC>{{cite report|url=http://www.defra.gov.uk/rwmac/reports/reprocess/16.htm |title=RWMAC's Advice to Ministers on the Radioactive Waste Implications of Reprocessing, Annex 4: Dry storage and disposal of Magnox spent fuel |author=Radioactive Waste Management Advisory Committee |publisher=[[Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs]] |date=November 2000 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060819040238/http://www.defra.gov.uk/rwmac/reports/reprocess/16.htm |archivedate=19 August 2006 |deadurl=yes }}</ref> As a [[carbon dioxide]] cooled, [[Nuclear graphite|graphite]] [[Neutron moderator|moderated]] Magnox reactor does not require difficult-to-produce [[enriched uranium]] fuel or a [[heavy water]] moderator it is an attractive choice for a wholly indigenous nuclear reactor development.
The Magnox facilities were disabled in 2007 in accord with the [[six-party talks]] agreement, but following the breakdown of that agreement were partially re-enabled in 2009 to reprocess existing stocks of spent fuel. On 15 September 2015, North Korea announced that the reactor had resumed operation.<ref name=bbc-20150915>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-34254634 |title=North Korea Yongbyon nuclear site 'in operation' |publisher=BBC |date=15 September 2015 |accessdate=15 September 2015 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150915114315/http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-34254634 |archivedate=15 September 2015 }}</ref>
The center also has an IRT-2000 pool-type [[research reactor]], supplied by the [[Soviet Union]] in 1963, operational since 1965.<ref>{{cite web |title=Research Reactor Details – IRT-DPRK |url=http://www.iaea.org/cgi-bin/rrdb.page.pl/rrdeta.htm?country=KP&site=IRT-DPRK&facno=258 |date=30 July 1996 |accessdate=14 February 2007 |publisher=International Atomic Energy Agency }}{{Dead link|date=September 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> The reactor fuel is IRT-2M type assemblies of 36% and 80% [[highly enriched uranium]].<ref name=hecker-20080314>{{Cite report|url=http://fsi.stanford.edu/publications/report_of_visit_to_north_korea_to_senate_foreign_relations_committee/ |title=Report of Visit to North Korea to Senate Foreign Relations Committee |author=Siegfried S. Hecker |date=14 March 2008 |publisher=[[Center for International Security and Cooperation]], Stanford University |accessdate=23 November 2010 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100628131231/http://fsi.stanford.edu/publications/report_of_visit_to_north_korea_to_senate_foreign_relations_committee/ |archivedate=28 June 2010 }}</ref><ref name=globalsecurity-dprk-nuclear>{{Cite web|url=http://www.globalsecurity.org/wmd/world/dprk/nuke.htm |title=DPRK – Nuclear Weapons Program |publisher=GlobalSecurity.org |accessdate=23 November 2010 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100302143552/http://www.globalsecurity.org/wmd/world/dprk/nuke.htm |archivedate=2 March 2010 }}</ref> As the center has not received fresh fuel since Soviet times, this reactor is now only run occasionally to produce [[iodine-131]] for [[thyroid cancer]] [[radiation therapy]].<ref name=albright-20070319>{{Cite report|url=http://www.isis-online.org/publications/dprk/CivilNuclearNK.pdf |title=Phased International Cooperation with North Korea’s Civil Nuclear Programs |author=David Albright |date=19 March 2007 |publisher=[[Institute for Science and International Security]] |accessdate=23 November 2010 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110720161656/http://www.isis-online.org/publications/dprk/CivilNuclearNK.pdf |archivedate=20 July 2011 }}</ref>
In 2009 the building of a small indigenous experimental [[light water reactor]] started. In 2010 a [[uranium enrichment]] plant began operating.<ref name=hecker-20101120/>
==History== [[File:Yongbyon 5 MWe reactor - fuel channels access ports.jpg|thumb|left|The 5 MWe reactor, showing the fuel channels access ports]] Construction of the 5 MWe experimental reactor began in 1980, and the reactor first went [[Critical mass|critical]] in 1986.<ref name=nyt-19920517/> This reactor was an initial small technology proving reactor for a following development program of larger Magnox reactors. The [[spent nuclear fuel]] reprocessing facility appeared to still be under construction in 1992.<ref name=nyt-19920517>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1992/05/17/world/north-korean-site-has-a-bomb-hints.html |title=North Korean site has A-bomb hints |author=Sheryl WuDunn |newspaper=New York Times |date=17 May 1992 |accessdate=18 March 2014 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140329145325/http://www.nytimes.com/1992/05/17/world/north-korean-site-has-a-bomb-hints.html |archivedate=29 March 2014 }}</ref> The 5 MWe experimental reactor operated intermittently until 1994 when it was shut down in accordance with the [[U.S.-North Korea Agreed Framework]]. Following the breakdown of the Agreed Framework in 2002, operation restarted in February 2003, creating [[plutonium]] within its fuel load at a rate of about 6 kg per year.<ref name=bridge-hecker-2010>{{Cite journal |url=http://cisac.stanford.edu/publications/north_koreas_choice_bombs_over_electricity/ |title=North Korea's Choice: Bombs Over Electricity |author1=Siegfried S. Hecker |author2=Sean C. Lee |author3=Chaim Braun |date=Summer 2010 |journal=The Bridge |volume=40 |issue=2 |pages=5–12 |publisher=[[National Academy of Engineering]] |accessdate=5 March 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101205175419/http://cisac.stanford.edu/publications/north_koreas_choice_bombs_over_electricity/ |archivedate=5 December 2010 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> The reactor fuel was replaced between April and June 2005. The [[spent nuclear fuel]] has been reprocessed with an estimated yield of about 24 to 42 kg of plutonium metal,<ref name=bridge-hecker-2010 /> some of which was used for the [[nuclear weapon]]s involved in the [[2006 North Korean nuclear test|2006]] and [[2009 North Korean nuclear test]]s.<ref name=NYT-10061017>[https://www.nytimes.com/2006/10/17/world/asia/17diplo.html North Korean Fuel Identified as Plutonium] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161219221406/http://www.nytimes.com/2006/10/17/world/asia/17diplo.html |date=19 December 2016 }}, Thom Shanker and David E. Sanger, [[New York Times]], 17 October 2006</ref>
Yongbyon is also the site of a 50 [[MWe]] Magnox prototype power reactor, but construction was halted in 1994 about a year from completion in accord with the Agreed Framework, and by 2004 the structures and pipework had deteriorated badly.<ref name=bas-hecker-20090512>{{Cite journal |url=http://www.thebulletin.org/web-edition/features/the-risks-of-north-koreas-nuclear-restart |title=The risks of North Korea's nuclear restart |author=Siegfried S. Hecker |date=12 May 2009 |publisher=[[Bulletin of the Atomic Scientists]] |accessdate=5 November 2009 |postscript=<!--None--> |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090715080143/http://thebulletin.org/web-edition/features/the-risks-of-north-koreas-nuclear-restart |archivedate=15 July 2009 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> This construction was being dismantled in 2010.<ref name=hecker-20101120 />
Another 200 MWe Magnox full-scale power reactor was being constructed at [[Taechon]], 20 km north-west of Yongbyon, ({{Coord|39.928|125.569|type:landmark_region:KP|display=inline}}) until construction was also halted in 1994 in accord with the Agreed Framework. By 2005 reconstruction of this reactor was uneconomic.
The reactor designs were based on declassified information about the British [[Magnox]] design at [[Calder Hall nuclear power station|Calder Hall]] and elsewhere, and the spent fuel reprocessing plant on the multi-national ''European Company for the Chemical Processing of Irradiated Fuels'' (EUROCHEMIC) plant at [[Mol, Belgium|Mol]]-[[Dessel]] in Belgium.<ref name=bridge-hecker-2010 />
===2007 shutdown=== [[File:Yongbyon, disabled nuclear fuel fabrication facility machine shop.jpg|thumb|Empty machine shop in the disabled fuel fabrication facility]] On 13 February 2007, an agreement was reached at the [[Six-party talks|Six party talks]] that [[North Korea]] will shut down and seal the Magnox nuclear reactor and associated facilities and invite back [[International Atomic Energy Agency]] personnel to conduct all necessary monitoring and verifications.<ref name="IAEA-GOV/2007/45-GC(51)/19">{{Cite journal|url=http://www.iaea.org/About/Policy/GC/GC51/GC51Documents/English/gc51-19_en.pdf |title=Application of Safeguards in the Democratic People's Republic of Korea (DPRK) |date=17 August 2007 |id=GOV/2007/45-GC(51)/19 |publisher=IAEA |accessdate=9 August 2009 |postscript=<!--None--> |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080509080157/http://www.iaea.org/About/Policy/GC/GC51/GC51Documents/English/gc51-19_en.pdf |archivedate=9 May 2008 }}</ref> In return for this [[North Korea]] will receive emergency energy assistance from the other five parties in the form of 50,000 tons of heavy fuel oil.
[[International Atomic Energy Agency]] (IAEA) inspectors arrived at the site on 28 June to discuss verification and monitoring arrangements for the shutdown.<ref>[http://edition.cnn.com/2007/WORLD/asiapcf/06/27/koreas.nuclear.ap/index.html?section=cnn_latest U.N. nuke inspectors go to N. Korea reactor], ''[[CNN]]'', published 2007-06-27, accessed 3 July 2007</ref> This had been delayed from April due to a dispute with the United States over [[Banco Delta Asia]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/asia-pacific/6461379.stm |title=N Korea warning on nuclear deal |author=James Reynolds |publisher=BBC News |date=17 March 2007 |accessdate=17 March 2007 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070320013226/http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/asia-pacific/6461379.stm |archivedate=20 March 2007 }}</ref> On 3 June an anonymous South Korean government official indicated that the shutdown may start following the first oil shipment later in the month.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/apps/news?pid=20601080&sid=aOV40WZ6Nk4M |title=North Korea Reactor Closure May Begin in Mid-July |author=Heejin Koo |publisher=[[Bloomberg L.P.|Bloomberg]] |date=3 July 2007 |accessdate=3 July 2007 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070927185015/http://www.bloomberg.com/apps/news?pid=20601080&sid=aOV40WZ6Nk4M |archivedate=27 September 2007 }}</ref> On 14 July, [[Sean McCormack]] stated that North Korea had told the US that the reactor had been shut down. He added that the US welcomed the news, and was awaiting verification from the IAEA team.<ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/asia-pacific/6899185.stm ''N Korea "closes nuclear reactor"''] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070922113411/http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/asia-pacific/6899185.stm |date=22 September 2007 }} [[BBC News]] retrieved 14 July 2007</ref> The next day, IAEA chief [[Mohamed ElBaradei]] announced the UN's confirmation that the reactor had been shut down.<ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/asia-pacific/6900184.stm "UN confirms N Korea nuclear halt"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070827185153/http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/asia-pacific/6900184.stm |date=27 August 2007 }}, ''[[BBC News]]'', 16 July 2007</ref> On 18 July 2007, the IAEA confirmed that all five nuclear facilities at Yongbyon had been shut down.<ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/asia-pacific/6903894.stm "N Korea closes more nuclear sites"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304113901/http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/asia-pacific/6903894.stm |date=4 March 2016 }}, ''BBC News'', 18 July 2007</ref>
In his Introductory Statement to the IAEA Board of Governors on 2008-03-03, the Director General stated that he could not provide an update on the disabling of the facilities, as it was not undertaken by the IAEA. All fuel rods from the 5 MWe Experimental Nuclear Power Plant and nuclear material generated by the disabling of the Nuclear Fuel Fabrication Plant were under IAEA containment and surveillance.<ref>"[http://www.iaea.org/NewsCenter/Statements/2008/ebsp2008n003.html#dprk Verification of Nuclear Non-Proliferation: Implementation of Safeguards in the DPRK] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080509155019/http://www.iaea.org/NewsCenter/Statements/2008/ebsp2008n003.html |date=9 May 2008 }}", IAEA: Statements of the Director General, Vienna, 2008-03-03. Retrieved on 26 April 2008</ref>
===2008 cooling tower demolition=== On Friday 27 June 2008, North Korea destroyed the most visible symbol of its nuclear weapons program – the [[cooling tower]] at its main atomic reactor in the complex. The implosion was witnessed by a number of international journalists and diplomats.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.theaustralian.news.com.au/story/0,25197,23933319-2703,00.html|title=Blast gets North Korea off US blacklist|date=28 June 2008|work=The Australian|accessdate=10 July 2008}} {{Dead link|date=September 2010|bot=H3llBot}}</ref>
The demolition of the {{convert|60|ft|m|adj=on}}-tall cooling tower, which carried off waste heat to the atmosphere, is a response to U.S. concessions after the North delivered a declaration of its nuclear programs to be dismantled. The United States paid the US$2.5 million demolition fee.{{Citation needed|date=July 2008}}
===Possible reactivation=== During 2008 tensions resurfaced between North Korea and the U.S. due to disagreements over the [[six-party talks]] disarmament process. On 8 October 2008, [[International Atomic Energy Agency|IAEA]] inspectors were forbidden by the North Korean government to conduct further inspections of the site. However two days later the U.S. removed North Korea from the U.S. [[State Sponsors of Terrorism]] list and the Yongbyon deactivation process resumed.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/90e15f8c-970d-11dd-8cc4-000077b07658.html |title=Bush removes North Korea from terror list |author=Demetri Sevastopulo |date=10 October 2008 |work=Financial Times |accessdate=10 October 2008 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081012123110/http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/90e15f8c-970d-11dd-8cc4-000077b07658.html |archivedate=12 October 2008 }}</ref>
===2009 resumption of reprocessing=== According to the state-run North Korean news agency KCNA website, the DPRK resumed the reprocessing of spent fuel to recover plutonium on 25 April 2009 in response to the UN's condemnation of its recent [[Kwangmyŏngsŏng-2|rocket launch]]. This material supplemented that used for nuclear weapons testing.<ref>{{cite news | title = North Korea says it has started reprocessing spent fuel rods | place = Nexis | publisher = BBC Monitoring Asia Pacific – Political | date = 25 April 2009 }}</ref>
===Light water reactor development=== In 2009 North Korea announced its intention to build an indigenous experimental [[light water reactor]] (LWR) and the uranium enrichment technology to provide its nuclear fuel.<ref name=kcna-20090613>{{Cite news|url=http://www.kcna.co.jp/item/2009/200906/news13/20090613-10ee.html |title=DPRK Foreign Ministry Declares Strong Counter- Measures against UNSC's "Resolution 1874" |date=13 June 2010 |publisher=[[Korean Central News Agency]] |accessdate=29 November 2010 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110609220635/http://www.kcna.co.jp/item/2009/200906/news13/20090613-10ee.html |archivedate=9 June 2011 }}</ref> In 2010 a 2,000 [[gas centrifuge]] uranium enrichment plant to produce [[low enriched uranium]] (LEU) fuel began operating, and construction started on the experimental 25 to 30 MWe LWR, with a target operation date for the reactor of 2012.<ref name=hecker-20101120>{{Cite report |url=http://cisac.stanford.edu/publications/north_koreas_yongbyon_nuclear_complex_a_report_by_siegfried_s_hecker/ |title=A Return Trip to North Korea’s Yongbyon Nuclear Complex |author=Siegfried S. Hecker |date=20 November 2010 |publisher=[[Center for International Security and Cooperation]], Stanford University |accessdate=21 November 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101125154041/http://cisac.stanford.edu/publications/north_koreas_yongbyon_nuclear_complex_a_report_by_siegfried_s_hecker |archivedate=25 November 2010 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> In November 2011, satellite imagery indicated that the LWR construction was progressing rapidly, with the concrete structures largely completed. The LWR is being built on the site of the demolished cooling tower of the experimental Magnox reactor.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://38north.org/2011/11/elwr111411/ |title=North Korea Makes Significant Progress in Building New Experimental Light Water Reactor (ELWR) |date=18 November 2011 |work=38 North, [[School of Advanced International Studies]] |publisher=Johns Hopkins University |accessdate=18 November 2011 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111117210831/http://38north.org/2011/11/elwr111411/ |archivedate=17 November 2011 }}</ref><ref name=hecker-20120106>{{Cite journal|url=http://thebulletin.org/web-edition/features/north-korea-30000-feet |title=North Korea from 30,000 feet |author1=Niko Milonopoulos |author2=Siegfried S. Hecker |author3=Robert Carlin |last-author-amp=yes |date=6 January 2012 |publisher=[[Bulletin of the Atomic Scientists]] |accessdate=19 January 2012 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120120043202/http://www.thebulletin.org/web-edition/features/north-korea-30000-feet |archivedate=20 January 2012 }}</ref> Following the building of this experimental LWR, North Korea intends to build larger LWRs for electricity generation.<ref name=hecker-20101120 /> Initial estimates were that the reactor would be put into operation in 2013,<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2012/08/31/us-nuclear-northkorea-iaea-idUSBRE87U0EH20120831 |title=North Korea makes "significant" nuclear reactor progress: IAEA |publisher=[[Reuters]] |date=31 August 2012 |accessdate=17 October 2012 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120919192635/http://www.reuters.com/article/2012/08/31/us-nuclear-northkorea-iaea-idUSBRE87U0EH20120831 |archivedate=19 September 2012 }}</ref> but the reactor was not externally complete until 2016.<ref name=38north-20160114>{{cite news|url=http://38north.org/2016/01/yongbyon011416/ |title=North Korea's Yongbyon Nuclear Facility: Slow Progress at the Experimental Light Water Reactor |publisher=U.S.-Korea Institute, Johns Hopkins University School of Advanced International Studies |work=38 North |date=14 January 2016 |accessdate=4 April 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160409200249/http://38north.org/2016/01/yongbyon011416/ |archivedate=9 April 2016 }}</ref> In 2017, several activities were noted involving construction, dam was built to provide sufficient amount of water for cooling system, switchyard and connections to transmission line were made along with facilities presumably used for maintenance and repair. Activity that suggests components were being transferred to the building were noted too.<ref>https://www.38north.org/2018/02/yongbyon021918/#_ftn4</ref> In 2018 the preliminary testing of the reactor started and expected activation is for 2018 or 2019.<ref>https://www.businesswire.com/news/home/20180316005225/en/Jane%E2%80%99s-IHS-Markit-Discovers-Operational-Testing-North</ref><ref>https://mobile.reuters.com/article/amp/idUSKCN1GS0B0</ref> The reactor is linked to power grid, expected output is 25 to 30 megawatts which is enough to supply homes with electricity for about 50,000 inhabitants.<ref>https://amp.cnn.com/cnn/2018/03/15/asia/north-korea-nuclear-reactors-activity/index.html</ref>
===Suspension of uranium enrichment=== In February 2012, North Korea announced that it would suspend uranium enrichment at Yongbyon, and not conduct any further tests of nuclear weapons while productive negotiations involving the United States continue. Additionally, North Korea would allow IAEA inspectors to monitor operations at Yongbyon. The U.S. reaffirmed that it does not have hostile intent toward the DPRK, and is prepared to improve bilateral relationships.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://kcna.co.jp/item/2012/201202/news29/20120229-37ee.html |title=DPRK Foreign Ministry Spokesman on Result of DPRK-U.S. Talks |publisher=Korean Central News Agency |date=29 February 2012 |accessdate=3 March 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120304080511/http://www.kcna.co.jp/item/2012/201202/news29/20120229-37ee.html |archivedate=4 March 2012 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.state.gov/r/pa/prs/ps/2012/02/184869.htm |title=U.S.-DPRK Bilateral Discussions |publisher=U.S. Department of State |date=29 February 2012 |accessdate=3 March 2012 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120302195255/http://www.state.gov/r/pa/prs/ps/2012/02/184869.htm |archivedate=2 March 2012 }}</ref> Nuclear enrichment was presumably resumed following the collapse of the Leap Day Deal.
===2013 planned restart of operation=== In March 2013, North Korea announced that they would be restarting operation of the 5 MWe experimental reactor.<ref name=bbc-20130402>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-21999193 |title=North Korea 'to restart Yongbyon nuclear reactor' |publisher=BBC |date=2 April 2013 |accessdate=11 April 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130407063220/http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-21999193 |archivedate=7 April 2013 }}</ref> In order to do so, the disabled secondary cooling system will have to be restored.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://38north.org/2013/04/yongbyon040313/ |title=Satellite Images Show New Construction at North Korea’s Plutonium Production Reactor; Rapid Restart? |author1=Nick Hansen |author2=Jeffrey Lewis |lastauthoramp=yes |date=3 April 2013 |work=38 North, [[School of Advanced International Studies]] |publisher=Johns Hopkins University |accessdate=11 April 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130407180539/http://38north.org/2013/04/yongbyon040313/ |archivedate=7 April 2013 }}</ref>
On 15 September 2015, North Korea announced that the Yongbyon nuclear site is in full operation, including the 5 MWe experimental reactor.<ref name=bbc-20150915/> However, satellite imagery in April 2016 suggested it was not operating at a high power level.<ref name=38north-20160415>{{cite news|url=http://38north.org/2016/04/yongbyon041516/ |title=More Evidence of Possible Reprocessing Campaign at Yongbyon; Progress at Experimental Light Water Reactor |author=Joseph S. Bermudez, Jr. |publisher=U.S.-Korea Institute, Johns Hopkins University School of Advanced International Studies |work=38 North |date=15 April 2016 |accessdate=17 April 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160416215811/http://38north.org/2016/04/yongbyon041516/ |archivedate=16 April 2016 }}</ref>
Infra-red imagery analysis covering from September 2016 to June 2017 showed that the 5 MWe experimental reactor had either not been operated, or operated at a low-level. The Radiochemical Laboratory had operated intermittently.<ref name=38north-20170714>{{cite news |url=http://www.38north.org/2017/07/yongbyon071417/ |title=North Korea's Yongbyon Facility: Probable Production of Additional Plutonium for Nuclear Weapons |author=Joseph S. Bermudez Jr., Mike Eley, Jack Liu. Frank V. Pabian |publisher=U.S.-Korea Institute, Johns Hopkins University School of Advanced International Studies |work=38 North |date=14 July 2017 |accessdate=15 July 2017}}</ref>
===2018 Pyongyang Agreement=== During the [[September 2018 inter-Korean summit#September 19 (Day 2)|September 2018 inter-Korean summit]], North Korean leader Kim Jung-Un and South Korean leader Moon Jae-In signed the "Pyongyang Joint Declaration of September 2018"<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.vox.com/2018/9/19/17878428/north-south-korea-kim-moon-declaration|title=North and South Korea just signed a major agreement. It may be bad news for Trump.|author=|date=|website=vox.com}}</ref> The agreement states, among other things, that the North Korean government will only dismantle Yongbyon if the US would engage in correlative action.<ref name="abc.net.au">{{cite web|url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/2018-09-19/north-korea-agrees-to-dismanlte-nuclear-test-site/10282040|title=South Korea says North agrees to dismantle nuclear site — if US takes reciprocal action|author=|date=19 September 2018|website=abc.net.au}}</ref>
===2018 South Korean Inspection=== A visit by officials from South Korea's National Intelligence Service revealed that Yongbyon has not participated in nuclear testing for the past year.<ref name=oct31>https://www.cnbc.com/2018/10/31/north-korea-reportedly-readies-nuclear-missile-sites-for-inspectors.html</ref> According to South Korean lawmaker Kim Min-ki, Yongbyon, which has yet to undergo the requirements needed for dismantling, saw no major movement in activity during the inspection.<ref name=oct31 />
==Organization== The Yongbyon facility was described in 2013<ref name="Structure">{{Cite web|url=http://www.koreanconfidential.com/northkoreanuclear.html |title=North Korea Nuclear R&D Structure |date=13 February 2013 |publisher=CRS |accessdate=26 March 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130411040725/http://www.koreanconfidential.com/northkoreanuclear.html |archivedate=11 April 2013 }}</ref> as operating the following ten sub-branches: # Isotope Utilization Institute # Neutron Physics Institute # Nuclear Electromagnetics Institute # Nuclear Physics Institute # Nuclear Material Institute # Nuclear Energy Research Institute # Uranium Resources Development Institute # Radiochemical Laboratory # Reactor Design Institute # Radiation Protection Institute
